statement.text: Equivalent Annual Cost (EAC) converts the total present value of project costs into an equivalent annual amount, enabling comparison of projects with different lifespans.
statement.formal: EAC = PV(costs) × r / [1 - (1+r)^(-n)] = PV(costs) / PVIFA(r, n)

explanation.intuition: When comparing equipment with different lifespans, we can't just compare total costs - a machine lasting 10 years will obviously cost more than one lasting 5 years. EAC puts costs on an 'annual rental' basis for fair comparison.
explanation.key_insight: EAC assumes projects can be repeated indefinitely. It's most appropriate for projects that will be replaced with similar alternatives when they end. For one-time projects, use adjusted present value methods instead.
explanation.technical_details: EAC is calculated by finding the annuity payment that has the same present value as the project's total costs. The project with the lower EAC is preferred, assuming revenues are the same or analyzed separately.
common_misconceptions: Higher upfront cost means higher EAC - not if the asset lasts longer or has lower operating costs
EAC comparison works for all projects - only valid when projects are repeatable
Revenues don't matter for EAC - they should be analyzed alongside or netted against costs

definitions_glossary.equivalent_annual_cost: Annual cost that has same PV as total project costs
definitions_glossary.PVIFA: Present Value Interest Factor of Annuity
definitions_glossary.repeatable_project: Project that will be replaced with similar investment when it ends
definitions_glossary.replacement_chain: Series of identical or similar projects over time

sources.citation: Brealey, R., Myers, S., & Allen, F. (2020). Principles of Corporate Finance. 13th Edition. McGraw-Hill.
Ross, S., Westerfield, R., & Jaffe, J. (2019). Corporate Finance. 12th Edition. McGraw-Hill.
sources.chapter: Chapter 7: Comparing Projects with Different Lives

learning_objectives: Calculate EAC from project present value
Compare projects with different lifespans using EAC
Understand when EAC analysis is appropriate
Apply EAC to equipment replacement decisions

examples.scenario: Machine A: Costs $10,000, lasts 3 years. Machine B: Costs $15,000, lasts 5 years. r=10%
